verses.text: Let all who are under the yoke of slavery regard their own masters as worthy of all respect, so that the name of God and the teaching may not be blasphemed.
verses.comment: Paul exhorts believers in servitude to show honor to their earthly masters for the sake of God's reputation and the Christian teaching. Spiritual obedience to authority is a recurring New Testament theme, reflecting a call to humility and order, as seen in Romans 13:1.

verses.text: And those who have believing masters must not despise them because they are brothers; instead, they must serve them even better, since those who benefit from their good service are believers and beloved. Teach and urge these things.
verses.comment: Paul instructs that Christian brotherhood should lead to deeper service, not contempt. The interconnectedness of believers, even across social structures, anticipates the early Church’s understanding of mutual care.

verses.text: If anyone teaches different doctrine and does not agree with the sound words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and the teaching that accords with godliness,
verses.comment: Fidelity to apostolic doctrine is essential. Any teaching diverging from Christ's authoritative instruction is to be rejected. The appeal to 'sound words' implies a body of teaching preserved in the early Church.

verses.text: he is puffed up with pride and understands nothing. He has an unhealthy craving for disputes and arguments about words, from which come envy, strife, abusive talk, evil suspicions,
verses.comment: False teaching leads to division, pride, and fruitless controversies. Paul warns against theological quarrels which disrupt peace within the assembly.

verses.text: and constant friction among people corrupted in mind and deprived of the truth, who imagine that godliness is a means of profit.
verses.comment: Some misuse religion for material gain. Paul exposes the dangers of equating godliness with financial prosperity, foreshadowing later warnings against those who would exploit faith for personal advantage.

verses.text: But godliness with contentment is great gain.
verses.comment: True spiritual wealth is found in living a godly life joined with contentment. This echoes Jesus' teaching on trust and detachment from worldly anxieties (Matt. 6:25-34).

verses.text: For we brought nothing into the world, and we cannot take anything out of it.
verses.comment: Here, Paul alludes to Old Testament wisdom, emphasizing the fleeting nature of material wealth and the importance of preparing for eternity.

verses.text: But if we have food and clothing, let us be content with that.
verses.comment: Paul advocates a spirit of simplicity and trust in God’s providence. Such humility and detachment from excess foster deeper reliance on God.

verses.text: But those who desire to be rich fall into temptation, into a trap, and into many foolish and harmful desires that plunge people into ruin and destruction.
verses.comment: Paul warns against the desire for riches, echoing Jesus’ parable of the sower (Matt. 13:22). The spiritual peril of greed often leads people away from faith’s safe path.

verses.text: For the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil, and some people, eager for it, have wandered away from the faith and pierced themselves with many pains.
verses.comment: Paul teaches that the love of money—not money itself—is dangerous. Greed can draw believers away from true faith. This highlights the need for a rightly ordered heart, aligned with Godly wisdom.

verses.text: But you, man of God, flee these things. Pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, love, endurance, and gentleness.
verses.comment: Paul exhorts Timothy—and all believers—to actively strive for virtues that reflect life in Christ, rather than worldly pursuits. This passage summarizes the character of true discipleship.

verses.text: Fight the good fight of faith; take hold of the eternal life to which you were called and about which you made the good confession in the presence of many witnesses.
verses.comment: Paul’s language evokes imagery of athletic competition and perseverance. 'The good confession' refers to the public profession of Christ, possibly baptism—a practice that became the gateway to full Christian initiation.

verses.text: I charge you in the presence of God, who gives life to all things, and of Christ Jesus, who made the good confession before Pontius Pilate,
verses.comment: Paul points to Christ's own confession before Pilate (John 18:36-37), highlighting the importance of fearless witness. The reference to 'God, who gives life' affirms the sovereignty of the Creator.

verses.text: to keep the commandment unstained and free from reproach until the appearing of our Lord Jesus Christ,
verses.comment: Believers are called to persevere in faith and holiness until Christ returns. The apostolic commandment here refers to the fullness of Christian life and teaching.

verses.text: which he will display at the proper time—he who is the blessed and only Sovereign, the King of kings and Lord of lords,
verses.comment: Christ is depicted with supreme divine authority ('King of kings and Lord of lords'), echoing both Old Testament and apocalyptic imagery. This affirms both the kingship and divinity of Christ.

verses.text: who alone possesses immortality, dwelling in unapproachable light, whom no one has ever seen or can see. To him be honor and eternal power. Amen.
verses.comment: The unique immortality and majesty of God are emphasized here, connecting Christ to Old Testament theophanies. The language underscores the transcendence and glory traditionally ascribed to God alone.

verses.text: Instruct those who are rich in this present age not to be proud, nor to put their hope in the uncertainty of riches, but in God, who richly provides us with all things to enjoy.
verses.comment: Paul draws a clear distinction between earthly and heavenly security, urging the wealthy to trust in God’s generosity. This passage subtly points towards using material resources for spiritual ends.

verses.text: They are to do good, to be rich in good works, generous and ready to share,
verses.comment: Charity and generosity are indispensable aspects of the Christian calling. Being 'rich in good works' echoes the teachings of James (James 2:14-17), connecting faith and concrete acts of love.

verses.text: thus storing up treasure for themselves as a good foundation for the future, so that they may take hold of that which is truly life.
verses.comment: Generosity builds a spiritual inheritance, reflecting Jesus’ teaching on treasures in heaven. This fulfills the principle of temporal things serving eternal purposes.

verses.text: O Timothy, guard what has been entrusted to you. Avoid the empty chatter and the contradictions of what is falsely called knowledge,
verses.comment: 'What has been entrusted' refers to the deposit of apostolic teaching, meant to be preserved and guarded. The warning against 'false knowledge' speaks against early forms of heresy, emphasizing the need for faithful transmission of truth.

verses.text: which some have professed and thus wandered away from the faith. Grace be with you.
verses.comment: Paul closes with a warning about those who departed from true faith by following novel teachings. His blessing, 'Grace be with you,' is both a personal and communal benediction, consistent with apostolic letters.
